items.author: Eric Kohn
items.content: More than a powerful elegy, 12 Years a Slave is a mesmerizing triumph of art and polemics: McQueen turns a topic rendered distant by history into an experience that, short of living through the terrible era it depicts, makes you feel as if you've been there.

items.author: Peter Debruge
items.content: Though the film brims with memorable characters, the show ultimately belongs to Ejiofor, who upholds the character’s dignity throughout.

items.author: The Guardian
items.content: Stark, visceral and unrelenting, 12 Years a Slave is not just a great film but a necessary one.

items.author: Tim Robey
items.content: Elicits from McQueen a directing job that's compellingly humble but also majestic, because his radical showmanship is turned to such precise, human purposes.

items.author: Richard Corliss
items.content: A document that is raw, eloquent, horrifying and essential.

items.author: David Denby
items.content: 12 Years a Slave is easily the greatest feature film ever made about American slavery.

items.author: The Playlist
items.content: This revolving door of graphically rendered brutalities might feel like its own punishment if not for an array of astonishing performances that’s practically a one-stop Oscar-nomination shopping spree.

items.author: Todd McCarthy
items.content: Perhaps the nature of the story is such that the film can’t help but be obvious and quite melodramatic at times, but it gets better as it goes along and builds to a moving finish.

items.author: William Goss
items.content: Ejiofor’s tightly clenched conviction perfectly embodies hope and righteousness against all odds. He gives the best performance of his career to date, and what’s more, he gives “Slave” its bruised, beating heart with every scene.

items.author: Ed Gonzalez
items.content: Steve McQueen's film practically treats Solomon Norhtup as passive observer to a litany of horrors that exist primarily for our own education.
